Pendle shares 44 suppliers with its neighbouring East Lancashire councils, with combined spending of £40.2 million across these shared suppliers. This is the highest number of shared suppliers of any council in our analysis, reflecting Pendle's broader supplier base of 3,019 unique companies.

Liberata UK Ltd: The Outsourcing Giant

The most striking shared supplier is Liberata UK Ltd, the outsourcing company that provides revenues and benefits services:

Council Total Paid to Liberata
Burnley£36,700,000
Pendle£16,700,000

Both councils outsource core services to the same company, but Burnley pays more than double what Pendle pays. While the scope of services may differ, this gap is large enough to warrant investigation. Are Burnley residents getting twice the service, or paying twice the price?

The 115,237% Price Gap

The most extreme price variation across all shared suppliers is Walton Summit Truck Centre Ltd:

Council Average Payment
Burnley£56,000
Pendle£49
115,237% gap — Burnley pays over 1,100 times more per transaction

This likely reflects fundamentally different services — Burnley may be purchasing vehicles while Pendle buys parts or services. But the comparison highlights why councils should benchmark their procurement against neighbours.

Key Takeaways for Pendle

  • Best Companies House compliance — only £37,800 to non-compliant suppliers, a fraction of neighbours
  • Most duplicate groups — 1,311 groups driven by the highest transaction volume of any council
  • Highest split payment exposure — £19.5M flagged as potential payment splitting
  • Most shared suppliers — 44 suppliers in common, enabling the most comprehensive price benchmarking
  • Unique transaction profile — many small payments (avg £2,604) vs Burnley's fewer large payments (avg £11,616)

The Opportunity

With 44 shared suppliers and £40.2 million in combined spending, there is a significant opportunity for Pendle to lead collaborative procurement across East Lancashire. The council's already-strong compliance record could serve as a model for its neighbours, while joint negotiations with shared suppliers could deliver savings for residents across all three boroughs.

Cross-council analysis based on publicly available spending data from Pendle, Hyndburn, and Burnley Borough Councils. Supplier matching performed using normalised company names.
